messageBody:
Robert Sanheim wrote:
> You cannot subclass a class with a private constructor, since the
> superclass constructor will not be visible for the "implicit"
> constructor to call. The compiler will choke on it.

Yes. I realized what I'd written after I sent it and left for lunch.
Obviously the constructor would need to be redeclared protected, and the
class can't be declared final. If neither of those is possible, then the
PrivateAccessor may work.

> On 6/23/05, jason r tibbetts <tibbettj@...> wrote:
>
>>mcgeejdw2004 wrote:
>>
>>>I have a class with a private constructor and a static factory method
>>>that returns an instance. I would like to run a Junit test that tests
>>>a few methods of this class but I do not want to make the constructor
>>>public and I would rather avoid creating a mock object to pass to the
>>>static factory because this could take some time to develop. What is
>>>the best way to handle this?
>>
>>JUnit-addons (http://sourceforge.net/projects/junit-addons) has a
>>PrivateAccessor class that allows you to do just what it says, although
>>I can't tell from the documentation (or state from experience) how you
>>can invoke the constructor with it.
>>
>>Or you can subclass the class, give it a public constructor, and test that.
